clusters.title: 9/24: CBS Evening News
clusters.neutral_headline: Deadly Shooting at Dallas ICE Facility Investigated

items.title: 9/24: CBS Evening News
items.standfirst: Everything we know about the deadly ICE facility shooting in Dallas; Fat Bear Week has arrived. Who will be crowned champion?
items.content: Everything we know about the deadly ICE facility shooting in Dallas; Fat Bear Week has arrived. Who will be crowned champion?

items.title: 9/24: CBS Evening News Plus
items.standfirst: Acting ICE director reacts to deadly shooting outside Dallas field office; Reporter's Notebook: The American Dream of generosity
items.content: Acting ICE director reacts to deadly shooting outside Dallas field office; Reporter's Notebook: The American Dream of generosity

items.title: Who is Joshua Jahn? What we know about the Dallas ICE facility shooting
items.standfirst: One person was killed and two injured by the gunman, who also took his own life. Jahn, the suspect, was 29.
items.content: One person was killed and two injured by the gunman, who also took his own life. Jahn, the suspect, was 29.

items.title: 'Anti-ICE' message on ammunition at Dallas shooting that killed immigration detainee
items.standfirst: The gunman fired at an unmarked van near the detention facility, before taking his own life, officials say.
items.content: The gunman fired at an unmarked van near the detention facility, before taking his own life, officials say.

items.title: ICE head says deadly Dallas facility shooting was an "indiscriminate" attack
items.standfirst: Todd Lyons, head of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, said the shooter "fired indiscriminately" into the ICE field office in Dallas and vehicles stationed there.
items.content: Todd Lyons, head of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, said the shooter "fired indiscriminately" into the ICE field office in Dallas and vehicles stationed there.

items.title: Deadly shooting at Dallas ICE facility investigated by FBI as targeted attack
items.standfirst: One person was killed and two people are in critical condition after a shooting at a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) field office in Dallas, authorities said.
items.content: One person was killed and two people are in critical condition after a shooting at a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) field office in Dallas, authorities said.

items.title: Reporter's Notebook: The American Dream of generosity
items.standfirst: A social media quote that's been circulating for years offers a reminder that the American Dream for many can simply mean the ability to give generously to others. "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson explains.
items.content: A social media quote that's been circulating for years offers a reminder that the American Dream for many can simply mean the ability to give generously to others. "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson explains.

items.title: Acting ICE director reacts to deadly shooting outside Dallas field office
items.standfirst: For the second time since July, there has been a shooting at an ICE facility in Texas. The gunman opened fire, killing at least one detainee inside a van and wounding two others, before taking his own life. Camilo Montoya-Galvez spoke to acting ICE director Todd Lyons.
items.content: For the second time since July, there has been a shooting at an ICE facility in Texas. The gunman opened fire, killing at least one detainee inside a van and wounding two others, before taking his own life. Camilo Montoya-Galvez spoke to acting ICE director Todd Lyons.

items.title: Shooter attacks ICE facility in Dallas, Texas, killing one detainee
items.standfirst: The Department of Homeland Security announced on Wednesday that a man with a rifle opened fire on a Dallas, Texas Immigration and Customs Enforcement location. This comes in the wake of increased border patrol measures, and a number of retaliatory attacks on ICE agents.
items.content: The Department of Homeland Security announced on Wednesday that a man with a rifle opened fire on a Dallas, Texas Immigration and Customs Enforcement location. This comes in the wake of increased border patrol measures, and a number of retaliatory attacks on ICE agents.

items.title: Shooting at ICE detention facility in Dallas kills 1 detainee, injures 2 others
items.standfirst: Authorities are investigating a fatal shooting Wednesday at a federal immigration detention facility in Dallas. One detainee was killed in what the FBI says was an act "of targeted violence."
items.content: Authorities are investigating a fatal shooting Wednesday at a federal immigration detention facility in Dallas. One detainee was killed in what the FBI says was an act "of targeted violence."(Image credit: Aric Becker)

ai_summary: A shooting at a Dallas ICE facility resulted in one death and two critical injuries, authorities reported.
The FBI is investigating the shooting as a targeted attack on the ICE field office in Dallas.
The acting ICE director stated the shooter fired "indiscriminately" at the facility and vehicles.
The gunman opened fire, killing a detainee inside a van and wounding two others before taking his life.
An "anti-ICE" message was found on ammunition used in the shooting, officials said.

clusters.title: Trump demands investigation over escalator, teleprompter ‘sabotage’ at UN
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Demands Investigation Over UN 'Triple Sabotage

items.title: Trump demands investigation over escalator, teleprompter ‘sabotage’ at UN
items.standfirst: US president says Secret Service is investigating 'three very sinister events' at UN headquarters in New York.
items.content: US president says Secret Service is investigating 'three very sinister events' at UN headquarters in New York.

items.title: Trump demands inquiry over UN 'triple sabotage' after escalator and teleprompter mishaps
items.standfirst: The US president called the incidents that included an escalator and teleprompter mishap "a real disgrace".
items.content: The US president called the incidents that included an escalator and teleprompter mishap "a real disgrace".

items.title: Escalatorgate: Trump alleges ‘triple sabotage’ after technical mishaps at UN
items.standfirst: Trump claims teleprompter and audio issues, and a stopped escalator that UN says may be due to US delegation stafferDonald Trump alleged “triple sabotage” at the United Nations, after the US president was plagued by a series of unfortunate events surrounding his address to the global body.“A REAL DISGRACE took place at the United Nations yesterday,” Trump wrote Wednesday in a 357-word social media chronicle of “Not one, not two, but three very sinister events!” Continue reading...
items.content: Trump claims teleprompter and audio issues, and a stopped escalator that UN says may be due to US delegation stafferDonald Trump alleged “triple sabotage” at the United Nations, after the US president was plagued by a series of unfortunate events surrounding his address to the global body.“A REAL DISGRACE took place at the United Nations yesterday,” Trump wrote Wednesday in a 357-word social media chronicle of “Not one, not two, but three very sinister events!” Continue reading...

items.title: Trump calls escalator and tech malfunctions at the UN 'triple sabotage'
items.standfirst: Following Tuesday's 'Escalatorgate,' in which US President Donald Trump faced escalator, sound system, and teleprompter malfunctions at the UN General Assembly, Trump announced on Wednesday that the Secret Service would be investigating the series of events. A UN spokesman responded by denying any foul play.
items.content: Following Tuesday's 'Escalatorgate,' in which US President Donald Trump faced escalator, sound system, and teleprompter malfunctions at the UN General Assembly, Trump announced on Wednesday that the Secret Service would be investigating the series of events. A UN spokesman responded by denying any foul play.

items.title: Trump alleges "triple sabotage" at U.N. after escalator and teleprompter freeze up
items.standfirst: A malfunctioning escalator and teleprompter at the United Nations' headquarters drew President Trump's frustration.
items.content: A malfunctioning escalator and teleprompter at the United Nations' headquarters drew President Trump's frustration.

items.title: Trump presents '21-point' plan to end Gaza war to Arab and Muslim leaders
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump, while meeting with Arab and Muslim leaders on Tuesday, announced a "21-point plan" to end the war in Gaza, his envoy said Wednesday. Several nations this week recognised the state of Palestine as world leaders met for the UN General Assembly.
items.content: US President Donald Trump, while meeting with Arab and Muslim leaders on Tuesday, announced a "21-point plan" to end the war in Gaza, his envoy said Wednesday. Several nations this week recognised the state of Palestine as world leaders met for the UN General Assembly.

ai_summary: Trump called for an investigation into technical mishaps at the UN, including an escalator issue.
He claimed "three very sinister events" occurred during his UN visit, including teleprompter problems.
The UN denied any foul play related to the technical malfunctions during Trump's address.
Trump announced the Secret Service would investigate the series of events at the UN headquarters.
Trump also presented a 21-point plan to end the war in Gaza to Arab and Muslim leaders.

clusters.title: Denmark airport closes due to drones, two days after incursions in Copenhagen and Oslo
clusters.neutral_headline: Drones Force Airport Closures in Denmark

items.title: Denmark airport closes due to drones, two days after incursions in Copenhagen and Oslo
items.standfirst: Police say the drones over Aalborg airport followed a similar pattern to the ones that had halted flights at Copenhagen airport a few days earlierDenmark’s Aalborg airport was closed for hours due to drones in its airspace, local police said early on Thursday, two days after the country’s main Copenhagen airport was shut over drone sightings that rattled European aviation.Danish national police said the drones followed a similar pattern to the ones that had halted flights at Copenhagen airport for four hours a few days earlier. The country’s armed forces were also affected, as Aalborg airport is used as a military base, they added. Continue reading...
items.content: Police say the drones over Aalborg airport followed a similar pattern to the ones that had halted flights at Copenhagen airport a few days earlierDenmark’s Aalborg airport was closed for hours due to drones in its airspace, local police said early on Thursday, two days after the country’s main Copenhagen airport was shut over drone sightings that rattled European aviation.Danish national police said the drones followed a similar pattern to the ones that had halted flights at Copenhagen airport for four hours a few days earlier. The country’s armed forces were also affected, as Aalborg airport is used as a military base, they added. Continue reading...

items.title: Drones spotted over four airports in Denmark
items.standfirst: Unidentified drones were spotted over four airports in Denmark late Wednesday and early Thursday, police told the media. According to the AFP News Agency, the sightings took place at Aalborg, Esbjerg...
items.content: Unidentified drones were spotted over four airports in Denmark late Wednesday and early Thursday, police told the media. According to the AFP News Agency, the sightings took place at Aalborg, Esbjerg...

items.title: Drones spotted over four Denmark airports, causing temporary closures
items.standfirst: Unidentified drones were observed over Aalborg, Esbjerg, Sonderborg and Skrydstrup airports in Denmark Wednesday night and early Thursday morning. This comes just two days after Copenhagen and Oslo airports were closed due to drone activity.
items.content: Unidentified drones were observed over Aalborg, Esbjerg, Sonderborg and Skrydstrup airports in Denmark Wednesday night and early Thursday morning. This comes just two days after Copenhagen and Oslo airports were closed due to drone activity.

items.title: Drones force another airport to close after Danish PM refuses to rule out Russian involvement
items.standfirst: An airport in Denmark, used for commercial and military flights, has been forced to close after drones were spotted in its airspace, local police have said.
items.content: An airport in Denmark, used for commercial and military flights, has been forced to close after drones were spotted in its airspace, local police have said.

ai_summary: Drones were spotted over four airports in Denmark, causing temporary closures and flight disruptions.
Aalborg airport was closed due to drones, following similar incidents at Copenhagen airport.
The Danish national police stated the drone activity followed a similar pattern to previous incidents.
The country's armed forces were also affected, as Aalborg airport is used as a military base.
The Danish PM refused to rule out Russian involvement in the drone incidents.

clusters.title: Marco Rubio meets with Russia's Sergei Lavrov after Trump shifts stance on Ukraine
clusters.neutral_headline: International Leaders Address the UN General Assembly

items.title: Marco Rubio meets with Russia's Sergei Lavrov after Trump shifts stance on Ukraine
items.standfirst: Secretary of State Marco Rubio met with Russia's foreign minister Sergei Lavrov on the sidelines of the U.N. General Assembly Wednesday. The meeting comes one day after President Trump appeared to shift his language regarding the war in Ukraine. CBS News intelligence and national security reporter Olivia Gazis has more.
items.content: Secretary of State Marco Rubio met with Russia's foreign minister Sergei Lavrov on the sidelines of the U.N. General Assembly Wednesday. The meeting comes one day after President Trump appeared to shift his language regarding the war in Ukraine. CBS News intelligence and national security reporter Olivia Gazis has more.

items.title: For the first time in nearly 6 decades, a Syrian president steps up to speak at the U.N.
items.standfirst: Turning the page on decades of distance, Syria's President Ahmad al-Sharaa addressed the U.N. General Assembly, marking the first time any president from his country has done so in almost 60 years.
items.content: Turning the page on decades of distance, Syria's President Ahmad al-Sharaa addressed the U.N. General Assembly, marking the first time any president from his country has done so in almost 60 years.(Image credit: Heather Khalifa)

items.title: In UN debut, new Syria leader warns on Israel but backs dialogue
items.standfirst: Syria's new leader warned Wednesday that Israel's persistent attacks put the region at risk, but he backed diplomacy as he won support on his UN debut. Ahmed al-Sharaa is the first Syrian president to address the annual UN General Assembly in decades, marking a rapid transformation for a former jihadist who until last year had a US bounty on his head. We speak to Aaron Y. Zelin, Senior Fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy.
items.content: Syria's new leader warned Wednesday that Israel's persistent attacks put the region at risk, but he backed diplomacy as he won support on his UN debut. Ahmed al-Sharaa is the first Syrian president to address the annual UN General Assembly in decades, marking a rapid transformation for a former jihadist who until last year had a US bounty on his head. We speak to Aaron Y. Zelin, Senior Fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy.

items.title: 'A speech calculated to appeal to Trump and the Global South'
items.standfirst: Reporting from Kyiv, FRANCE 24's correspondent Gulliver Cragg says Volodymyr Zelenskyy's speech at the United Nations General Assembly was one very much calculated to please US President Donald Trump and 'to appeal to the Global South, to people who are far from Europe but might think that this war in Ukraine poses a threat to them in ways they hadn't perhaps previously imagined'.
items.content: Reporting from Kyiv, FRANCE 24's correspondent Gulliver Cragg says Volodymyr Zelenskyy's speech at the United Nations General Assembly was one very much calculated to please US President Donald Trump and 'to appeal to the Global South, to people who are far from Europe but might think that this war in Ukraine poses a threat to them in ways they hadn't perhaps previously imagined'.

items.title: Ukraine’s president says the world is in `the most destructive arms race in human history’
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told global leaders Wednesday that the world is in “the most destructive arms race in human history” and urged the international community to act against Russia now, asserting that Vladimir Putin wants to expand his war in Europe. FRANCE 24's Carys Garland reports.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told global leaders Wednesday that the world is in “the most destructive arms race in human history” and urged the international community to act against Russia now, asserting that Vladimir Putin wants to expand his war in Europe. FRANCE 24's Carys Garland reports.

items.title: New Syrian leader hails country's 'return' in first UN speech since Assad's fall
items.standfirst: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa addressed the UN General Assembly on Wednesday, the first Syrian leader to do so in nearly six decades, declaring the country’s return to the international community after the Assad regime’s fall last December. Al-Sharaa, who led the insurgent offensive that toppled Bashar al-Assad, said Syria was reclaiming its “rightful place” after decades of dictatorship.
items.content: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa addressed the UN General Assembly on Wednesday, the first Syrian leader to do so in nearly six decades, declaring the country’s return to the international community after the Assad regime’s fall last December. Al-Sharaa, who led the insurgent offensive that toppled Bashar al-Assad, said Syria was reclaiming its “rightful place” after decades of dictatorship.

items.title: Ukraine's Zelenskyy issues a stark warning about a global arms race and AI war
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addressed the U.N. General Assembly a day after President Trump made another shift in his stance on Russia's war in Ukraine.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addressed the U.N. General Assembly a day after President Trump made another shift in his stance on Russia's war in Ukraine.(Image credit: Richard Drew)

items.title: Zelenskyy's UN speech was in perfect English - and served as a warning
items.standfirst: Volodymyr Zelenskyy's moment in the United Nations General Assembly chamber came a day after he told Sky News that Donald Trump's language represented a "big shift" in America's stance on Ukraine.
items.content: Volodymyr Zelenskyy's moment in the United Nations General Assembly chamber came a day after he told Sky News that Donald Trump's language represented a "big shift" in America's stance on Ukraine.

ai_summary: Marco Rubio met with Russia's Sergei Lavrov on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly.
Syria's new leader addressed the UN, marking the first time in nearly six decades.
The Syrian leader warned of risks from Israeli attacks but supported dialogue.
Ukraine's president said the world is in the most destructive arms race in history.
Zelenskyy's speech was calculated to appeal to Trump and the Global South.

clusters.title: Deadly Super Typhoon Ragasa kills at least 17 people
clusters.neutral_headline: Super Typhoon Ragasa Causes Destruction in Asia

items.title: Deadly Super Typhoon Ragasa kills at least 17 people
items.standfirst: Super Typhoon Ragasa is barreling through Asia, slamming Hong Kong with heavy rain and winds. The storm has closed schools and businesses. Taiwanese officials say at least 17 people have died and many are missing. NBC News’ Janis Mackey Frayer reports.
items.content: Super Typhoon Ragasa is barreling through Asia, slamming Hong Kong with heavy rain and winds. The storm has closed schools and businesses. Taiwanese officials say at least 17 people have died and many are missing. NBC News’ Janis Mackey Frayer reports.

items.title: Deadly Typhoon Ragasa leaves path of destruction in east Asia
items.standfirst: Typhoon Ragasa, the most powerful tropical storm on Earth this year, hammered southern China after killing at least 20 people in the Philippines and Taiwan. NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer has more on the deadly storm.
items.content: Typhoon Ragasa, the most powerful tropical storm on Earth this year, hammered southern China after killing at least 20 people in the Philippines and Taiwan. NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer has more on the deadly storm.

items.title: As it happened – deadly cyclone makes landfall in China after devastating Hong Kong, Taiwan and Philippines
items.standfirst: This blog is now closed, you can read more on this story here:Ragasa: 17 killed in Taiwan as storm batters Hong KongIn pictures: Ragasa’s path of destructionSuper Typhoon Ragasa is the strongest storm of 2025 and is now bearing down on China’s southern coast.The Guardian’s picture desk have put together this gallery showing some of the damage and scenes being witnessed in Hong Kong, Taiwan, the Philippines and China. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Typhoon Ragasa makes landfall in China after 17 killed in Taiwan
items.standfirst: Ragasa is the world's strongest storm this year and has been roaring over the South China Sea for days.
items.content: Ragasa is the world's strongest storm this year and has been roaring over the South China Sea for days.

items.title: Super typhoon slams into Hong Kong after killing at least 17 in Taiwan
items.standfirst: Streets in southern China were deserted on Wednesday as Typhoon Ragasa, one of the world’s strongest storms this year, slammed into the region after carving a deadly path between the Philippines and Taiwan.
items.content: Streets in southern China were deserted on Wednesday as Typhoon Ragasa, one of the world’s strongest storms this year, slammed into the region after carving a deadly path between the Philippines and Taiwan.

items.title: Super typhoon hits China and Hong Kong after 17 killed in Taiwan
items.standfirst: At least 17 people have been killed in an area of Taiwan popular with tourists after super typhoon Ragasa lashed the island nation, with Hong Kong and mainland China also impacted.
items.content: At least 17 people have been killed in an area of Taiwan popular with tourists after super typhoon Ragasa lashed the island nation, with Hong Kong and mainland China also impacted.

ai_summary: Super Typhoon Ragasa slammed into Hong Kong after devastating Taiwan and the Philippines.
At least 17 people died in Taiwan due to the typhoon, with many still missing.
Ragasa is the strongest storm of the year, impacting southern China with heavy rain and winds.
Streets in southern China were deserted as the typhoon hit the region.
The storm closed schools and businesses in Hong Kong and other affected areas.

items.standfirst: Two have been taken to hospital with serious shrapnel injuries, the Magen David Adom ambulance service says.
items.content: Two have been taken to hospital with serious shrapnel injuries, the Magen David Adom ambulance service says.

items.standfirst: Two people seriously injured, says national ambulance service as military says drone was launched from YemenAt least 20 people have been injured, two seriously, after a drone launched from Yemen hit Israel’s Red Sea resort city of Eilat on the border with Jordan and Egypt.Police said the drone fell in Eilat’s city centre, causing damage in the area frequented by tourists. Continue reading...

items.title: At least 20 injured after drone strike on southern Israel, ambulance service says
items.standfirst: At least 20 people were injured on Wednesday after a drone launched from Yemen hit Israel’s Red Sea resort city of Eilat on the border with Jordan and Egypt, the Israeli national ambulance service Magen David Adom said
items.content: At least 20 people were injured on Wednesday after a drone launched from Yemen hit Israel’s Red Sea resort city of Eilat on the border with Jordan and Egypt, the Israeli national ambulance service Magen David Adom said

ai_summary: A drone launched from Yemen hit Eilat, Israel, injuring at least twenty people.
Two people were seriously injured in the drone strike on the Israeli city.
The drone fell in Eilat's city center, causing damage in a tourist area.
The attack was claimed by Yemen's Houthis, who launched the drone.
The Israeli military and ambulance service responded to the attack.

items.title: ‘Raring to go:’ the German remote-driving firm that hopes to make private car ownership redundant
items.standfirst: Europe has been slow to embrace robotaxis but Germany will allow remote-controlled rental cars from December Having been summoned by a few clicks in an app, the electric car slows to a halt outside the former cargo hall of Berlin’s now defunct Tegel airport. No one is at the wheel, but upon a…

No one is at the wheel, but upon a…

items.title: ‘Raring to go:’ the German remote-driving firm that hopes to make private car ownership redundant
items.standfirst: Europe has been slow to embrace robotaxis but Germany will allow remote-controlled rental cars from DecemberHaving been summoned by a few clicks in an app, the electric car slows to a halt outside the former cargo hall of Berlin’s now defunct Tegel airport. No one is at the wheel, but upon a passenger stepping inside, a voice announces: “This is Bartek, I am your driver today. Please buckle up and we can be on our way.”The car emits a friendly jingle, then makes its way to the former runway, where it performs a fault-free manoeuvre around a route marked by traffic cones. Continue reading...
items.content: Europe has been slow to embrace robotaxis but Germany will allow remote-controlled rental cars from DecemberHaving been summoned by a few clicks in an app, the electric car slows to a halt outside the former cargo hall of Berlin’s now defunct Tegel airport. No one is at the wheel, but upon a passenger stepping inside, a voice announces: “This is Bartek, I am your driver today. Please buckle up and we can be on our way.”The car emits a friendly jingle, then makes its way to the former runway, where it performs a fault-free manoeuvre around a route marked by traffic cones. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A German remote-driving firm hopes to make private car ownership unnecessary.
Germany will allow remote-controlled rental cars starting in December.
The cars can be summoned via an app and are driverless.

items.standfirst: Though registration kiosks are due to open in UK in two weeks, system may not be fully enforced for nine monthsBiometric registration to visit the EU may not be fully enforced for another nine months, with border officials allowed to relax the rules to alleviate queues or chaos at ports after the system finally goes live.In just over two weeks, Eurotunnel, Eurostar and the Port of Dover will all open new biometric registration kiosks in the UK, installed at a cost of tens of millions of pounds. items.standfirst: The iPhone-maker criticises Brussels’ Digital Markets Act and says delayed features are leading to a worse experience for users Apple has called for the European Commission to repeal a swathe of technology legislation, warning that unless it is amended the company could stop shipping some products and services to the 27-country bloc.In the latest of a series of clashes with Brussels, the iPhone maker said the Digital Markets Act was leading to a worse experience for Apple users, exposing them to security risks, and disrupting the seamless way Apple products work together. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Paris court to rule on Nicolas Sarkozy corruption charge

items.title: Paris court to rule on Nicolas Sarkozy corruption charge
items.standfirst: Former president and others accused of receiving millions of euros in illegal election funding from Libyan regime of Muammar GaddafiEurope live – latest updatesA Paris court is to rule whether the former French president Nicolas Sarkozy is guilty of receiving millions of euros in illegal election campaign funding from the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi, in the biggest political financing scandal in modern French history.Judges will deliver their verdict on Thursday after the state prosecutor recommended a seven-year jail term for Sarkozy, who went on trial with 12 other people – including three former government ministers – accused of criminal conspiracy to receive funds from a foreign dictator. Sarkozy and the other accused have denied wrongdoing. Continue reading...
items.content: Former president and others accused of receiving millions of euros in illegal election funding from Libyan regime of Muammar GaddafiEurope live – latest updatesA Paris court is to rule whether the former French president Nicolas Sarkozy is guilty of receiving millions of euros in illegal election campaign funding from the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi, in the biggest political financing scandal in modern French history.Judges will deliver their verdict on Thursday after the state prosecutor recommended a seven-year jail term for Sarkozy, who went on trial with 12 other people – including three former government ministers – accused of criminal conspiracy to receive funds from a foreign dictator. Sarkozy and the other accused have denied wrongdoing. Continue reading...

items.title: French ex-president Sarkozy faces verdict over Libya campaign financing
items.standfirst: A French court is set to deliver its verdict Thursday in the trial of former president Nicolas Sarkozy, accused of taking illegal campaign funds from Libya’s late strongman Muammar Gaddafi, with prosecutors demanding a seven-year sentence. The ruling comes days after the death of a key accuser.
items.content: A French court is set to deliver its verdict Thursday in the trial of former president Nicolas Sarkozy, accused of taking illegal campaign funds from Libya’s late strongman Muammar Gaddafi, with prosecutors demanding a seven-year sentence. The ruling comes days after the death of a key accuser.

ai_summary: A Paris court will rule on the Nicolas Sarkozy corruption case.

items.title: Malawi’s 85-year-old ex-leader returns to power in presidential election
items.standfirst: Lazarus Chakwera, who presided over a multi-year economic crisis, concedes election after Peter Mutharika wins 56.8% of voteMalawians have voted in an 85-year-old former leader over an incumbent who presided over a multi-year economic crisis, high inflation, essential goods shortages, climate disasters and international aid cuts.Peter Mutharika got 56.8% of the vote compared with 33% for Lazarus Chakwera, according to official results of the 16 September presidential election announced on Wednesday. Continue reading...
